I am able to reproduce locally with 
` tools/run_tests/run_tests.py -l c -c dbg -r 'h2_http_proxy_nosec_test.*shutdown_finishes_calls' -n 100`

Assert at shutdown_finishes_calls.cc:166 is failing with GRPC_STATUS_UNKNOWN (status == 2) and details "Stream removed".

Some insight into what's happening:

- everything's going fine and server shutdown is requested and cancellation of all calls is requested https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/cab345efe666f03739e2ae7ef11696c486d47716/test/core/end2end/tests/shutdown_finishes_calls.cc#L154

- the backend server shuts down

- in a case where the test passes, the proxy sees an "server read" error (because the backend has shutdown)  of  `I0228 15:51:00.457000000  8320 http_proxy_fixture.cc:152] HTTP proxy server read:
 {"created":"@1519833060.457000000","description":"End of TCP stream","file":"C:\cygwin64\home\builder\grpc\src\core\lib\iomgr\tcp_windows.cc","file_line":186}` and shuts down the "client_endpoint" , which results in the actual client call to fail with expected status (INTERNAL or UNAVAILABLE).

- in a case where the test fails, the server read on the proxy fails with ` http_proxy_fixture.cc:152] HTTP proxy server read: {"created":"@1519833002.546000000","description":"An established connection was aborted by the software in your host machine.\r\n","file":"C:\cygwin64\home\builder\grpc\src\core\lib\iomgr\tcp_windows.cc","file_line":174}`,
the client_endpoint of the proxy is also closed, but this time that results in the client call finishing with the UNKNOWN status, which fails the test.
@yashykt  do you have any insight into what could be happening? This flake has been plaguing us for a long time, so I'd like to finally resolve it.

After lots of debugging, I think I have the explanation for what's happening:

1. Under normal circumstances, the server gets shutdown and the pending call is cancelled. GOAWAY and RST_STREAM is sent on the wire, it gets forwarded by the http proxy to the grpc client and the test finishes with success.

2. In the failure case, the server get shutdown correctly and the pending call is cancelled. GOAWAY and RST_STREAM is sent back to the proxy (I've verified that while debugging) and the server's tcp endpoint (winsocket) goes for shutdown.  In most cases, the GOAWAY and RST_STREAM are received by the proxy and forwarded to the client (which results in the test passing). 

3. But concurrently with the pending read from 2 (that would receive the GOAWAY and RST_STREAM frames) other things are happening: because we've just established a tcp connection, HTTP/2 ping frames are being exchanged between the client and the server (they are forwarded through the proxy).  What happens is that the client sends ping to the proxy and the proxy forwards the ping frame to the server. But if the timing is right, the attempt to write to the server happens *after* the server has requested shutdown of its TCP endpoint. It looks like that when we try to write to a socket after the peer has closed, this will end up in  WSAECONNABORTED (10053) error on our pending read (that would otherwise deliver GOAWAY and RST_STREAM, that have been correctly written by the server), and the proxy cannot forward these frames to the client and it just closes the connection with client. So the client call ends up with UNKNOWN status code instead, which fails the test.

4. Indeed, all the failures I've seen reported `http_proxy_fixture.cc:152] HTTP proxy server read: {"created":"@1519833002.546000000","description":"An established connection was aborted by the software in your host machine.\r\n","file":"C:\cygwin64\home\builder\grpc\src\core\lib\iomgr\tcp_windows.cc","file_line":174}`. The string "An established connection was aborted by the software in your host machine" corresponds to WSAECONNABORTED (10053).
Nice work Jan! This certainly does seem like the right reason.
This flake has been mitigated by merging #14560, but we a also filed a tracking issue https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/14643 to revisit the socket shutdown problem.
This was seen again on v1.11.x branch which includes the fix on #14992.
